<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp005" view="all">Reactions between the di-sodium salt of amino terepthalic acid and a lanthanide chloride lead to a family of 3D-coordination polymers. Their crystal structure exhibits large channels with square cross-section. The channels are filled by crystallization water molecules. The dehydration of the compounds by freeze-drying is possible. The porosity of the dehydrated compounds is 2170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.<ce:display>

</ce:figure>
</ce:display>

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Reactions between the di-sodium salt of amino terepthalic acid and a lanthanide chloride lead to a family of 3D-coordination polymers. Their crystal structure exhibits large channels with square cross-section. The channels are filled by crystallization water molecules. The dehydration of the compounds by freeze-drying is possible. The porosity of the dehydrated compounds is 2170m2 g-1.

<ce:section-title>Research highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp010" view="all">► We have synthesized potentially porous lanthanide based coordination polymers. ► These compounds present large cavities (49<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) fill by water molecules. ► Most of the water molecules can be removed at room temperature. ► The porosity of the dehydrated compound has been estimated to more than 2000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. ► These compounds are obtained from low cost reagents by a green synthetic process.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Research highlights

► We have synthesized potentially porous lanthanide based coordination polymers. ► These compounds present large cavities (49Å2) fill by water molecules. ► Most of the water molecules can be removed at room temperature. ► The porosity of the dehydrated compound has been estimated to more than 2000m2 g-1. ► These compounds are obtained from low cost reagents by a green synthetic process.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Reactions in water between the di-sodium salt of amino terepthalic acid (C8H3NO4Na2) and a lanthanide chloride lead to a family of 3D-coordination polymers with general chemical formula [Ln(C8H3NO4)(C8H4NO4), O]∞ where Ln=La-Eu (except Pm) and 8⩽ n ⩽11. All these compounds are isostructural. High quality single crystals of [Ln(C8H3NO4)(C8H4NO4), nH2O]∞ with Ln=La-Sm (except Pm) and 8⩽ n ⩽11 have been obtained by slow diffusion in agar-agar gels. The crystal structure has been solved for the Nd-containing compound. This compound crystallizes in the cubic system, space group Ia-3 (no. 206) with a =26.8056(5)Å. The crystal structure can be described as the juxtaposition of large channels with square cross-section.

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="sp020" view="all">The channels are filled by highly disordered crystallization water molecules. The dehydration of the compounds by freeze-drying is possible and most of the crystallization water molecules can be removed without destruction of the molecular skeleton. The partially dehydrated compounds have general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), 2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> with Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>La–Eu except Pm. The porosity of the Nd-containing compound has been estimated by computational methods to 2170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. This dehydrated compound reversibly binds water when exposed to wet atmosphere restoring the initial hydrated phase.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: The channels are filled by highly disordered crystallization water molecules. The dehydration of the compounds by freeze-drying is possible and most of the crystallization water molecules can be removed without destruction of the molecular skeleton. The partially dehydrated compounds have general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), 2H2O]∞ with Ln=La-Eu except Pm. The porosity of the Nd-containing compound has been estimated by computational methods to 2170m2 g-1. This dehydrated compound reversibly binds water when exposed to wet atmosphere restoring the initial hydrated phase.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">For almost a decade the number of reported Molecular Open Frameworks is steadily increasing . This renewal of interest is mainly due to their potential interest for de-pollution or gas storage purposes. Despite the huge number of reported compounds, there are still relatively few examples of lanthanide containing MOFs . Some of us are currently studying lanthanide containing coordination polymers aiming materials exhibiting porosity  or interesting luminescent properties  and respectful of environment. Therefore, for more than 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>years we are developing a green synthetic strategy  implying water as solvent, non-toxic reagents, high yield reactions conducted at ambient temperature and pressure and gel media for crystal growth . These requirements have led us to synthesize numerous lanthanide containing coordination polymers involving benzene-poly-carboxylate ligands . Actually, benzene-poly-carboxylate ligands have drawn much attention because they are chemically and thermally stable, present a structuring effect thanks to π-stacking, and carboxylato functional groups allow one to expect a structural diversity due to their numerous possible coordination modes . The synthesis of lanthanide containing coordination framework exhibiting porosity after removing the crystallization water molecules requires to maintain the host framework integrity in the absence of guest molecules in order to allow reversible access to the cavities within the host. Obviously 3D coordination framework is needed for such a purpose. However despite the high coordination numbers presented by the lanthanide ions, 3D coordination polymers are rather uncommon and the choice of the organic binding ligands seems to be a key point. Among the benzene-poly-carboxylate based compounds, the terephthalate containing ones revealed to be particularly interesting . On the other hand, the amino-substituted benzene-poly-carboxylate ligands tend to promote 3D molecular structure when associated with lanthanide ions . We have thus undertaken the study of the amino-terephthalate/Ln(III) system in water (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0075"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

For almost a decade the number of reported Molecular Open Frameworks is steadily increasing . This renewal of interest is mainly due to their potential interest for de-pollution or gas storage purposes. Despite the huge number of reported compounds, there are still relatively few examples of lanthanide containing MOFs . Some of us are currently studying lanthanide containing coordination polymers aiming materials exhibiting porosity  or interesting luminescent properties  and respectful of environment. Therefore, for more than 10years we are developing a green synthetic strategy  implying water as solvent, non-toxic reagents, high yield reactions conducted at ambient temperature and pressure and gel media for crystal growth . These requirements have led us to synthesize numerous lanthanide containing coordination polymers involving benzene-poly-carboxylate ligands . Actually, benzene-poly-carboxylate ligands have drawn much attention because they are chemically and thermally stable, present a structuring effect thanks to π-stacking, and carboxylato functional groups allow one to expect a structural diversity due to their numerous possible coordination modes . The synthesis of lanthanide containing coordination framework exhibiting porosity after removing the crystallization water molecules requires to maintain the host framework integrity in the absence of guest molecules in order to allow reversible access to the cavities within the host. Obviously 3D coordination framework is needed for such a purpose. However despite the high coordination numbers presented by the lanthanide ions, 3D coordination polymers are rather uncommon and the choice of the organic binding ligands seems to be a key point. Among the benzene-poly-carboxylate based compounds, the terephthalate containing ones revealed to be particularly interesting . On the other hand, the amino-substituted benzene-poly-carboxylate ligands tend to promote 3D molecular structure when associated with lanthanide ions . We have thus undertaken the study of the amino-terephthalate/Ln(III) system in water ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this paper we describe the synthesis of coordination polymers with general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> where Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>La–Eu (except Pm) and 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>⩽<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>⩽<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11. Their dehydration by freeze-drying leads to a new family of porous compounds with general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), 2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> where Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>La–Eu (except Pm). The porosity of the partially dehydrated Nd-containing compound has been evaluated by computational methods to more than 2000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. To the best of our knowledge this is the greatest porosity ever reported for lanthanide containing coordination polymers. This is of particular interest as far as heterogeneous catalysis is concerned because this family of compounds involves the lightest lanthanide ions which are well known for their catalytic properties .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this paper we describe the synthesis of coordination polymers with general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), nH2O]∞ where Ln=La-Eu (except Pm) and 8⩽ n ⩽11. Their dehydration by freeze-drying leads to a new family of porous compounds with general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), 2H2O]∞ where Ln=La-Eu (except Pm). The porosity of the partially dehydrated Nd-containing compound has been evaluated by computational methods to more than 2000m2 g-1. To the best of our knowledge this is the greatest porosity ever reported for lanthanide containing coordination polymers. This is of particular interest as far as heterogeneous catalysis is concerned because this family of compounds involves the lightest lanthanide ions which are well known for their catalytic properties .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The crystal structure has been solved on the Nd-containing compound. The isostructurality of the other compounds have been assumed on the basis of their X-ray powder diffraction diagrams and single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. This compound crystallizes in the cubic system, space group Ia-3, with the following cell parameters: <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>26.8056(5)Å, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>19260.9(2)Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> and <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>24. These parameters have already been reported previously for a Nd- and a Pr-containing compounds  but the quality of the crystals did not allow precise crystal structure determinations. Consequently, it has been suggested that these two compounds present different crystal structures despite their very similar cell parameters. Thanks to the good quality of the single crystals obtained in gel medium, it is now possible to demonstrate that all the compounds [Ln(adbc)(Hadbc), <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] with Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>La–Eu are isostructural.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The crystal structure has been solved on the Nd-containing compound. The isostructurality of the other compounds have been assumed on the basis of their X-ray powder diffraction diagrams and single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. This compound crystallizes in the cubic system, space group Ia-3, with the following cell parameters: a =26.8056(5)Å, V =19260.9(2)Å3 and Z =24. These parameters have already been reported previously for a Nd- and a Pr-containing compounds  but the quality of the crystals did not allow precise crystal structure determinations. Consequently, it has been suggested that these two compounds present different crystal structures despite their very similar cell parameters. Thanks to the good quality of the single crystals obtained in gel medium, it is now possible to demonstrate that all the compounds [Ln(adbc)(Hadbc), nH2O] with Ln=La-Eu are isostructural.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The crystal structure can be described as the juxtaposition of cubic-like molecular motifs in which the apexes are occupied by tri-metallic entities bound to each other by amino terephthalate ligands (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure can be described as the juxtaposition of cubic-like molecular motifs in which the apexes are occupied by tri-metallic entities bound to each other by amino terephthalate ligands (see  ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent metal ions (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Nd1 occupies a 8b Wickoff position and Nd2 a 16c one. Each trinuclear entity is constituted by one central Nd1 and two external Nd2. Therefore the three Nd(III) ions forming a trinuclear entity are perfectly aligned. Nd1 is bound to 12 oxygen atoms from six amino-terephthalate groups forming a slightly distorted icosahedron. Nd2 is bound to nine oxygen atoms belonging to six amino terephthalate groups and forming a slightly distorted dodecahedron. The three coordination polyhedrons are linked together in a face-shared manner (See 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). It is noticeable that the surrounding of the lanthanide ions is overcrowded and no coordination water molecule can enter the coordination spheres. This is rather uncommon for lanthanide-based coordination polymers synthesized in aqueous media but it has already been observed . This overcrowding explains why it has not been possible to obtain homologous compounds involving the heaviest lanthanide ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent metal ions (see  ). Nd1 occupies a 8b Wickoff position and Nd2 a 16c one. Each trinuclear entity is constituted by one central Nd1 and two external Nd2. Therefore the three Nd(III) ions forming a trinuclear entity are perfectly aligned. Nd1 is bound to 12 oxygen atoms from six amino-terephthalate groups forming a slightly distorted icosahedron. Nd2 is bound to nine oxygen atoms belonging to six amino terephthalate groups and forming a slightly distorted dodecahedron. The three coordination polyhedrons are linked together in a face-shared manner (See  ). It is noticeable that the surrounding of the lanthanide ions is overcrowded and no coordination water molecule can enter the coordination spheres. This is rather uncommon for lanthanide-based coordination polymers synthesized in aqueous media but it has already been observed . This overcrowding explains why it has not been possible to obtain homologous compounds involving the heaviest lanthanide ions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The nitrogen atom is disordered over three positions: it can be linked to C6 (as represented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>) but also to C5 or C2. These three positions are equiprobable. Only the carbon atom C3 cannot be substituted by the amino group probably because of steric hindrance. Furthermore, EDS analyses have been done for compounds [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> with Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>La–Eu except Pm. In all cases they confirm the absence of any free cation in the crystal structure. Therefore, for insuring electroneutrality of the compounds, one amino-terephthalate out of two must be once protonated. The FTIR spectra suggest that the amino group is protonated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The nitrogen atom is disordered over three positions: it can be linked to C6 (as represented in  ) but also to C5 or C2. These three positions are equiprobable. Only the carbon atom C3 cannot be substituted by the amino group probably because of steric hindrance. Furthermore, EDS analyses have been done for compounds [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), nH2O]∞ with Ln=La-Eu except Pm. In all cases they confirm the absence of any free cation in the crystal structure. Therefore, for insuring electroneutrality of the compounds, one amino-terephthalate out of two must be once protonated. The FTIR spectra suggest that the amino group is protonated.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">As the compound crystallizes in the cubic system, the crystal structure develops identically in the three directions of the space. In each direction, the molecular skeleton can be described as a double chain of trinuclear entities that spreads in a helicoidal way (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As the compound crystallizes in the cubic system, the crystal structure develops identically in the three directions of the space. In each direction, the molecular skeleton can be described as a double chain of trinuclear entities that spreads in a helicoidal way (see  ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The only crystallization water molecule present in the crystal structure is located between the ligands in the vicinity of the tri-nuclear entities. It is bound to the molecular skeleton via a strong network of hydrogen bonds involving the both the oxygen atoms and the nitrogen atom of the neighboring amino terephthalate ligands (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The only crystallization water molecule present in the crystal structure is located between the ligands in the vicinity of the tri-nuclear entities. It is bound to the molecular skeleton via a strong network of hydrogen bonds involving the both the oxygen atoms and the nitrogen atom of the neighboring amino terephthalate ligands (see  ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Consequently, from a crystallographic point of view, the big square-cross cavities are empty and the calculated density of the compound is very low (1.11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>). At this point, this compound looks like a “spontaneously porous” material. In order to evaluate its porosity we have used a computational method, based on Connolly’s algorithm . elements.clean_text: As shown in , the dehydrated compound losses its crystallinity upon heating but the molecular skeleton must remain unchanged because the initial crystal structure is restored by simple exposition to wet atmosphere at room temperature. In order to explain this strange thermo-gravimetric analysis we have carefully checked the homogeneity of the initial microcrystalline powder. As can be seen in  , it is clearly monophasic and no significant impurity is observed. Furthermore, a thermo-gravimetric analysis has been performed on a sample constituted by single crystals obtained by slow evaporation. This led to exactly the same results than the one realized on a microcrystalline sample. At last, the X-ray diffraction diagram of the residual powder (after the thermo-gravimetric experiment) confirmed it is only composed of Nd2O3.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">At this point, we are faced to a family of potentially porous compounds that need activation. The Thermally Dependent X-ray Diffraction measurements clearly show that the compound collapses as soon as it is heated. Therefore, the activation must be done by freeze drying . The X-ray diffraction diagram of the resulting powder clearly shows that the crystalline character of the compound is retained upon the freeze drying process. Unfortunately, the usual loss of crystallinity during this process and the complexity of the crystal structure did not allow the fitting of the cell parameters. However, we are convinced that the slight change in the XRD pattern (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>) only reflects a small contraction of the molecular network due the departure of the most labile crystallization water molecules. The thermo-gravimetric analysis of the sample revealed that the compound has been only partially dehydrated. Usually, only coordinated water molecules remain in the structure after a freeze-drying . This is probably related to the strong hydrogen bonds networks that links the two localized crystallization water molecules to the molecular skeleton. Due to these strong interactions these two water molecules per formula unit remain bounded even after the freeze drying process while the others are removed.</ce:para>

It is noticeable (see  ) that the disordered crystallization water molecules are so weakly bound to the molecular network that it is possible to remove them at room temperature under a flux of N2.

At last this partially dehydrated compound spontaneously re-hydrates when exposed for 12h to wet atmosphere leading to the initial hydrated phase.

Conclusions and outlook

We have synthesized and characterized a new family of potentially porous lanthanide based coordination polymers with general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), nH2O]∞ with Ln=La-Eu (except Pm) and 8⩽ n ⩽11. These compounds present large square-cross cavities (49Å2) fill by crystallization water molecules. These crystallization water molecules are so weakly bound to the molecular network that it is possible to remove most of them at room temperature by a simple flux of dry nitrogen. The partially dehydrated compound have general formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), 2H2O]∞ with Ln=La-Eu (except Pm). Their porosity has been estimated by computational method to more than 2000m2 g-1 which constitutes a record in the field of lanthanide-containing coordination polymers. Despite their low thermal stability these compounds could be very interesting as far as technological applications with low temperature use are concerned. Indeed, they are obtained from relatively low cost reagents by a green synthetic process with a good yield, they present a very high porosity and their activation is energetically thrifty. Furthermore, the family contains the Ce-based compound which could present some interest in heterogeneous catalysis.

Experimental

Synthesis of the microcrystalline powders [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), nH2O]∞ with Ln=La-Eu (except Pm) and 8⩽ n ⩽11

2-Amino-benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (H2abdc) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. Di-sodium amino-terephthalate salt is prepared by addition of two equivalents of sodium hydroxide to a suspension of amino-terephthalic acid in de-ionized water. The obtained solution is then evaporated to dryness. The resulting solid is put in suspension in ethanol and the mixture is stirred and refluxed for 1h. After filtration and drying, a pale yellow powder of di-sodium 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate is collected in 90% yield.

For pattern indexing, the extractions of the peak positions were carried out via the <ce:small-caps>winplotr</ce:small-caps>
 software. The pattern indexing was performed by the program <ce:small-caps>mcmaille</ce:small-caps>
, and the refinement of the unit-cell parameters by means of the <ce:small-caps>chekcell</ce:small-caps> program which is a modified version of Cellref from CRYSFIRE suite .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
FTIR measurements

FT-IR spectra have been measured on KBr pellets between 400 and 4000cm-1 using a Perkin-Elmer Paragon 1000 PC spectrometer.

X-ray powder diffraction

The diagrams have been collected using a Panalytical X'Pert Pro diffractometer with a X'celerator detector. The typical recording conditions were 40kV, 40mA for Cu Kα (λ =1.542Å), the diagrams were recorded in θ/θ mode in 60min between 5° and 75° (8378 measurements) with a step size of 0.0084° and a scan time of 50s. The calculated patterns were produced using the powdercell and winplotr software programs . For pattern indexing, the extractions of the peak positions were carried out via the winplotr  software. The pattern indexing was performed by the program mcmaille , and the refinement of the unit-cell parameters by means of the chekcell program which is a modified version of Cellref from CRYSFIRE suite .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermal analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0185" view="all">Thermo-gravimetric and thermal differential analyses were performed in a platinum crucible under a nitrogen atmosphere between room temperature and 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a heating rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C·min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> using a Perkin–Elmer Pyris-Diamond thermal analyzer. At the end of the experiment, the compounds were maintained for 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under air atmosphere in order to complete the combustion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis

Thermo-gravimetric and thermal differential analyses were performed in a platinum crucible under a nitrogen atmosphere between room temperature and 1000°C with a heating rate of 5°C⋅min-1 using a Perkin-Elmer Pyris-Diamond thermal analyzer. At the end of the experiment, the compounds were maintained for 1h at 1000°C under air atmosphere in order to complete the combustion.

All crystals have been sealed in glass capillaries for X-ray single crystal data collection in order to avoid potential dehydration. Single crystals were mounted on a APEXII AXS-Bruker diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The crystal data collections were performed at 100K.

elements.clean_text:
Absorption corrections were performed using the facilities  included in the wingx program suite .

The structure was solved by direct methods using the sir97 program , and then refined with full matrix least-square methods based on F 2 (shelx-97)  with the aid of wingx program . The contribution of the disordered solvents to the calculated structure factors was estimated following the BYPASS algorithm , implemented as the squeeze option in platon . A new data set, free of solvent contribution, was then used in the final refinement. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the shelxl program . Hydrogen atoms bound to the organic ligand were localized at ideal positions. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules have not been localized. Crystal and final structure refinement data of [Nd(abdc)(Habdc), nH2O]∞are listed in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Scanning electron microscopy – energy dispersive spectroscopy (SEM-EDS analysis)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0205" view="all">All SEM observations and EDS measurements were carried out with a Hitachi TM-1000, Tabletop Microscope version 02.11 (Hitachi High-Technologies, Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) with EDS analysis system (SwiftED-TM, Oxford Instruments Link INCA). The detector type is a Silicon drift detector, with an energy resolution of 165<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV which allows us to detect the element from Na to U. With the software SwiftED-TM, qualitative and quantitative analyses can be realized. All the samples have been observed by means of an electron beam accelerated at 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV, under high vacuum. The samples were assembled on carbon discs, stuck on an aluminum stub fixed at 7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm from EDX beam, with an angle of measurement of 22°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Scanning electron microscopy - energy dispersive spectroscopy (SEM-EDS analysis)

All SEM observations and EDS measurements were carried out with a Hitachi TM-1000, Tabletop Microscope version 02.11 (Hitachi High-Technologies, Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) with EDS analysis system (SwiftED-TM, Oxford Instruments Link INCA). The detector type is a Silicon drift detector, with an energy resolution of 165eV which allows us to detect the element from Na to U. With the software SwiftED-TM, qualitative and quantitative analyses can be realized. All the samples have been observed by means of an electron beam accelerated at 15kV, under high vacuum. The samples were assembled on carbon discs, stuck on an aluminum stub fixed at 7mm from EDX beam, with an angle of measurement of 22°.

cln_elements.clean_text:
In this paper we describe the synthesis of coordination polymers with general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), nH2O]∞ where Ln=La-Eu (except Pm) and 8⩽ n ⩽11. Their dehydration by freeze-drying leads to a new family of porous compounds with general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), 2H2O]∞ where Ln=La-Eu (except Pm). The porosity of the partially dehydrated Nd-containing compound has been evaluated by computational methods to more than 2000m2 g-1. To the best of our knowledge this is the greatest porosity ever reported for lanthanide containing coordination polymers. This is of particular interest as far as heterogeneous catalysis is concerned because this family of compounds involves the lightest lanthanide ions which are well known for their catalytic properties .

Experimental

Synthesis of the microcrystalline powders [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), nH2O]∞ with Ln=La-Eu (except Pm) and 8⩽ n ⩽11

2-Amino-benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (H2abdc) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. Di-sodium amino-terephthalate salt is prepared by addition of two equivalents of sodium hydroxide to a suspension of amino-terephthalic acid in de-ionized water. The obtained solution is then evaporated to dryness. The resulting solid is put in suspension in ethanol and the mixture is stirred and refluxed for 1h. After filtration and drying, a pale yellow powder of di-sodium 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate is collected in 90% yield.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Reactions between the di-sodium salt of amino terepthalic acid and a lanthanide chloride lead to a family of 3D-coordination polymers. Their crystal structure exhibits large channels with square cross-section. The channels are filled by crystallization water molecules. The dehydration of the compounds by freeze-drying is possible. The porosity of the dehydrated compounds is 2170m2 g-1.     

The channels are filled by highly disordered crystallization water molecules. The dehydration of the compounds by freeze-drying is possible and most of the crystallization water molecules can be removed without destruction of the molecular skeleton. The partially dehydrated compounds have general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), 2H2O]∞ with Ln=La-Eu except Pm. The porosity of the Nd-containing compound has been estimated by computational methods to 2170m2 g-1. This dehydrated compound reversibly binds water when exposed to wet atmosphere restoring the initial hydrated phase.

Results and discussion

The crystal structure has been solved on the Nd-containing compound. The isostructurality of the other compounds have been assumed on the basis of their X-ray powder diffraction diagrams and single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. This compound crystallizes in the cubic system, space group Ia-3, with the following cell parameters: a =26.8056(5)Å, V =19260.9(2)Å3 and Z =24. These parameters have already been reported previously for a Nd- and a Pr-containing compounds  but the quality of the crystals did not allow precise crystal structure determinations. Consequently, it has been suggested that these two compounds present different crystal structures despite their very similar cell parameters. Thanks to the good quality of the single crystals obtained in gel medium, it is now possible to demonstrate that all the compounds [Ln(adbc)(Hadbc), nH2O] with Ln=La-Eu are isostructural.

Consequently, from a crystallographic point of view, the big square-cross cavities are empty and the calculated density of the compound is very low (1.11gcm-3). At this point, this compound looks like a "spontaneously porous" material. In order to evaluate its porosity we have used a computational method, based on Connolly's algorithm . This method has already been described and successfully used elsewhere . Thanks to it, the porosity profile of a partially dehydrated material can be design on the basis of its crystal structure. The porosity profile of [Nd(abdc)(Habdc), 2H2O]∞ is reported in  .

From this figure one can notice that molecules with kinetic radii  as big as 3.5Ǻ can penetrate the molecular framework. The potential porosity calculated with a probe sphere radius of 1.8Å (the kinetic radius of a N2 molecule) is 2170m2 g-1. This value is, to the best of our knowledge, the most important potential porosity reported for lanthanide containing coordination polymers .

It is noticeable (see  ) that the disordered crystallization water molecules are so weakly bound to the molecular network that it is possible to remove them at room temperature under a flux of N2.

At last this partially dehydrated compound spontaneously re-hydrates when exposed for 12h to wet atmosphere leading to the initial hydrated phase.

Conclusions and outlook

We have synthesized and characterized a new family of potentially porous lanthanide based coordination polymers with general chemical formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), nH2O]∞ with Ln=La-Eu (except Pm) and 8⩽ n ⩽11. These compounds present large square-cross cavities (49Å2) fill by crystallization water molecules. These crystallization water molecules are so weakly bound to the molecular network that it is possible to remove most of them at room temperature by a simple flux of dry nitrogen. The partially dehydrated compound have general formula [Ln(abdc)(Habdc), 2H2O]∞ with Ln=La-Eu (except Pm). Their porosity has been estimated by computational method to more than 2000m2 g-1 which constitutes a record in the field of lanthanide-containing coordination polymers. Despite their low thermal stability these compounds could be very interesting as far as technological applications with low temperature use are concerned. Indeed, they are obtained from relatively low cost reagents by a green synthetic process with a good yield, they present a very high porosity and their activation is energetically thrifty. Furthermore, the family contains the Ce-based compound which could present some interest in heterogeneous catalysis.

Elemental Anal. Calc. for C8H5O4NNa2 (MW=225g.mol-1): C, 42.7; H, 2.2; O, 28.5; N, 6.2; Na, 20.4. Found: C, 42.5; H, 2.0; O, 28.7; N, 6.4;Na, 20.4%

Hydrated lanthanide chlorides were prepared from the corresponding oxides according to literature methods . Lanthanide oxides were purchased from STREM Chemicals and used without further purification.
